content.statement: arch-003-zone-classification is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Aortic-Arch-Disease Definitions that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding arch-003-zone-classification helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of arch-003-zone-classification include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of arch-003-zone-classification.

zone_0.anatomic_boundary: Ascending aorta, proximal to origin of innominate artery
zone_0.extends_to: Proximal margin of innominate artery origin
zone_0.vessels_covered: All arch vessels (innominate, left carotid, left subclavian)
zone_0.device_considerations: Requires ascending aorta-compatible device, risk of coronary ostial coverage
zone_0.special_risks: Retrograde Type A dissection (2-5%), coronary occlusion

zone_1.anatomic_boundary: Between innominate artery and left common carotid artery
zone_1.extends_from: Distal margin of innominate artery origin
zone_1.extends_to: Proximal margin of left common carotid artery origin
zone_1.vessels_covered: Innominate artery (if covered), left carotid, left subclavian
zone_1.notes: Short zone, often combined with Zone 0 in practice

zone_2.anatomic_boundary: Between left common carotid artery and left subclavian artery
zone_2.extends_from: Distal margin of left carotid origin
zone_2.extends_to: Proximal margin of left subclavian artery origin
zone_2.vessels_covered: Left carotid and left subclavian (if covered)
zone_2.notes: Common landing zone for descending pathology with inadequate Zone 3

zone_3.extends_from: Distal margin of left subclavian artery origin
zone_3.vessels_covered: Left subclavian artery if landing proximal in zone
zone_3.notes: Most common elective TEVAR landing zone

zone_4.notes: Ideal landing zone - no arch vessel management needed

planning_considerations.seal_zone_length: Minimum 20mm of healthy, non-angulated aorta recommended

device_selection.zone_1_2: Standard thoracic devices with appropriate proximal diameter

planning_considerations.angulation: Greater curvature (outer curve) preferred for landing; inner curve has more angulation
planning_considerations.thrombus_calcium: Avoid landing in heavily calcified or thrombotic segments

clinical_applications.emergent_trauma: Zone 3-4 typically sufficient for blunt aortic injury
clinical_applications.aneurysm: Zone determined by proximal extent of aneurysm
clinical_applications.dissection_type_B: Zone 2-3 commonly needed for proximal seal
clinical_applications.penetrating_ulcer: Zone dictated by ulcer location plus seal zone

innominate_bypass.technique: Ascending aorta to innominate artery graft

left_carotid_revascularization.indication: Zone 2 landing with left carotid coverage
options: Ascending aorta to left carotid bypass

definition.@value: Classification system dividing the aortic arch into zones 0-4 based on great vessel landmarks, used for planning endovascular thoracic aortic repair and determining revascularization requirements

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Define zones 0-4 of the aortic arch using anatomic landmarks
Identify which vessels are covered when landing in each zone
Determine revascularization requirements for each zone
Select appropriate landing zone based on pathology location
clinical_pearls: Zone 0 landing requires complete debranching and sternotomy
Zone 3 is the most common elective TEVAR landing zone
Always consider left subclavian revascularization if covered - arm ischemia, vertebral steal, spinal cord supply
Minimum 20mm healthy seal zone recommended for adequate proximal fixation
Inner curve of arch has greater angulation - outer curve preferred for landing
